Literature Review: Sequential Monte Carlo (SMC) methods, also known as particle filters, have emerged as powerful tools for addressing complex filtering problems in nonlinear state-space systems. These methods have gained significant attention in the scientific community due to their ability to provide approximate solutions to problems that are often intractable using traditional analytical approaches. This literature review aims to explore the development, applications, and recent advancements in SMC methods.The origins of SMC methods can be traced back to the seminal work of Gordon et al. (1993), who introduced the bootstrap filter as a novel approach to nonlinear filtering. This groundbreaking paper laid the foundation for subsequent research in particle filtering techniques. The bootstrap filter demonstrated the potential of using Monte Carlo methods to approximate posterior distributions in state-space models, opening up new possibilities for tackling complex estimation problems.Building upon this initial work, Kitagawa (1996) further developed the concept of particle filtering by proposing a more general framework for nonlinear filtering. This research contributed to the broader understanding of SMC methods and their applicability to a wide range of problems in signal processing and beyond.One of the key advantages of SMC methods is their ability to handle non-Gaussian noise and nonlinear dynamics in state-space models. Traditional approaches, such as the extended Kalman filter, often struggle with these challenges. Arulampalam et al. (2002) provided a comprehensive tutorial on particle filters, highlighting their superiority in dealing with nonlinear and non-Gaussian scenarios. This work has become a cornerstone reference for researchers and practitioners in the field.As the field of SMC methods matured, researchers began to explore various improvements and extensions. Doucet et al. (2000) introduced the auxiliary particle filter, which aimed to enhance the efficiency of particle filtering by incorporating current observations into the proposal distribution. This innovation led to improved performance in many applications, particularly those involving highly informative measurements.Another significant development in SMC methods was the introduction of the unscented particle filter by van der Merwe et al. (2000). This approach combined the unscented Kalman filter with particle filtering techniques, resulting in a more accurate and computationally efficient algorithm for nonlinear state estimation.The versatility of SMC methods has led to their application in numerous domains. In the field of target tracking, Hue et al. (2002) demonstrated the effectiveness of particle filters for multi-target tracking in cluttered environments. Their work showcased the ability of SMC methods to handle complex scenarios with multiple objects and measurement uncertainties.In the realm of robotics and autonomous systems, SMC methods have played a crucial role in simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) problems. Montemerlo et al. (2002) proposed FastSLAM, a particle filter-based algorithm for SLAM that significantly improved upon existing techniques. This research highlighted the potential of SMC methods in solving challenging problems in robotics and computer vision.The application of SMC methods has also extended to financial modeling and econometrics. Johannes et al. (2009) employed particle filtering techniques for estimating stochastic volatility models in finance. Their work demonstrated the effectiveness of SMC methods in capturing complex dynamics in financial time series data.Recent years have seen continued advancements in SMC methods, with researchers focusing on improving their efficiency and scalability. Naesseth et al. (2019) introduced nested sequential Monte Carlo methods, which provide a framework for handling hierarchical models and improving particle diversity. This development has opened up new possibilities for applying SMC methods to increasingly complex problems.In conclusion, Sequential Monte Carlo methods have revolutionized the field of nonlinear filtering and state estimation. From their inception with the bootstrap filter to recent advancements in nested SMC, these techniques have consistently demonstrated their power and versatility across various domains. As research in this area continues to evolve, SMC methods are likely to play an increasingly important role in addressing complex estimation problems in fields ranging from signal processing and robotics to finance and beyond.
